subsection.title: Exponential Growth
subsection.p: Suppose that every year, only 10% of the fish in a lake have surviving offspring. If there were 100 fish in the lake last year, there would now be 110 fish. If there were 1000 fish in the lake last year, there would now be 1100 fish. Absent any inhibiting factors, populations of people and animals tend to grow by a percent of the existing population each year.

Let's make a sequence listing the population of fish in a lake each year. Suppose our lake began with 1000 fish, and 10% of the fish have surviving offspring each year. Since we start with 1000 fish, P_0 = 1000. How do we calculate the population for the next year? The new population will be the old population, plus an additional 10%. Symbolically, the next term is:

While 10% is the growth rate, 1.10 is the growth multiplier. Notice that 1.10 can be thought of as “the original 100% plus an additional 10%”.

Notice that in the first year, the population grew by 100 fish, in the second year, the population grew by 110 fish, and in the third year the population grew by 121 fish. While there is a constant percentage growth, the actual number of fish added is increasing each year.
Graphing these values we see that this growth doesn't quite appear linear.

sidebyside.p: To get a better picture of how this percentage-based growth affects things, we need a faster way to calculate values further out in the future. Just as we found a faster way to do repeated addition with linear models, here we need a quick way to do repeated multiplication.

subsection.p: Like we did for the linear model, let's start building each term of the sequence from the initial term, and see if we can find a pattern:
It makes sense that we end up using exponents here. Just as multiplication is repeated addition, exponentiation is repeated multiplication.
Observing a pattern, we can generalize to a formula for the population (P) of fish after any number (n) of years: P = 1.10^n(1000) or equivalently P = (1000)1.10^n.
From this, we can quickly calculate the number of fish in 10, 20, or 30 years:

sidebyside.p: Adding these values to our graph reveals a shape that is definitely not linear. If our fish population had been growing linearly, by 100 fish each year, the population would have only reached 4000 in 30 years compared to almost 18000 with this percent-based growth, called exponential growth.

subsection.p: In exponential growth, the population grows proportional to the size of the population, so as the population gets larger, the same percent growth will yield a larger numeric growth.

assemblage.title: Exponential Sequences
assemblage.p: A sequence is exponential if it changes by a common percentage.
We call the common percentage the percent growth rate, which in decimal form is designated as r. In the case of our fish population, r = 0.10.

The common ratio or growth multiplier for an exponential sequence is the number you multiply each term by to get the next term. The growth multiplier is always equal to 1+r. In the case of our fish population, the growth multiplier is 1.10.

If r is positive (equivalently, if the growth multiplier is greater than 1), the sequence is increasing and we say that it exhibits exponential growth. If r is negative (equivalently, if the growth multiplier is less than 1), the sequence is decreasing and we say that it exhibits exponential decay.
If a quantity starts at size P_0 and grows by R% (written as a decimal, r) every time period, then the quantity P after n time periods can be determined using this formula:

In the equation, P_0 = 4600,which is the starting value of the tuition when n = 0. This tells us that the tuition in 2010 was $4,600.
The growth multiplier is 1.072, so the growth rate is 0.072, or 7.2%. This tells us that the tuition is expected to grow by 7.2% each year.
Putting this together, we could say that the tuition in 2010 was $4,600, and is expected to grow by 7.2% each year.

assemblage.title: Rounding
assemblage.p: As a note on rounding, notice that if we had rounded the growth rate to 2.1%, our calculation for the emissions in 2050 would have been 3347. Rounding to 2% would have changed our result to 3156. A very small difference in the growth rates gets magnified greatly in exponential growth. For this reason, it is recommended to round the growth rate as little as possible.

If you need to round, keep at least three significant - numbers after any leading zeros. So 0.4162 could be reasonably rounded to 0.416. A growth rate of 0.001027 could be reasonably rounded to 0.00103.

assemblage.title: Evaluating roots on the calculator
assemblage.p: In the previous example, we had to calculate the 10th root of a number. This is different than taking the basic square root, \sqrt{}. Many scientific calculators have a button for general roots. It is typically labeled like: \sqrt[n]{} \text{, } \sqrt[x]{} \text{, or } \sqrt[y]{x}
To evaluate the 3rd root of 8, for example, we'd either type 3 \sqrt[x]{} 8 or 8 \sqrt[y]{x} 3, depending on the calculator. Try it on yours to see which to use - you should get an answer of 2.

If your calculator does not have a general root button, all is not lost. You can instead use the property of exponents which states that \sqrt[n]{a} = a^{\frac{1}{n}}. So to compute the 3rd root of 8, you could use your calculator's exponent key to calculate 8^{\frac{1}{3}}. To do this, type: 8 y^x (1 \div 3).
The parentheses tell the calculator to divide 1/3 before doing the exponent.

subsection.title: Logistic Growth
subsection.p: In our basic exponential growth scenario, we assumed that the growth rate would remain constant. In many situations, however, exponential growth is unsustainable, and the growth rate will decrease over time.

In a lake, for example, there is some maximum sustainable population of fish, also called a carrying capacity. If the population in the lake is far below the carrying capacity, then we would expect the population to grow essentially exponentially. However, as the population approaches the carrying capacity, there will be a scarcity of food and space available, and the growth rate will decrease, until the population levels out around the carrying capacity. We call this kind of growth logistic growth.

figure.title: Exponential vs. Logistic Growth
figure.caption: Comparing exponential and logistic models of fish in a lake. The carrying capacity used in this logistic model is 10,000 fish.

assemblage.title: Logistic growth
assemblage.p: When a quantity initially grows exponentially, but grows more and more slowly over time until it levels off, this is known as logistic growth.

subsection.p: Although populations will generally grow exponentially over the short term when they start well below the carrying-capacity, over the long term populations tend to grow logistically, since there are always limited resources in real environments that eventually slow a population's growth. Logistic growth is also used to model other situations that would at first appear exponential:

ul.li: The number of people infected by a new pathogen.
The concentration of the products of a chemical reaction.
The prevalence of a specific variation in a language, like a new word or phrase.
Crop yield, varying with the amount of fertilizer used.
The spread of new ideas or innovations.

conclusion.p:
So how do we know which growth model—linear, exponential, or logistic—to use when working with data? There are two approaches which should be used together whenever possible:
Find more than two pieces of data. Plot the values, and look for a trend. Does the data appear to be changing like a line, or do the values appear to be curving upwards and/or leveling off?
Consider the factors contributing to the data. Are they things you would expect to change by a constant amount or a percentage, i.e., linearly or exponentially? If they change by a percentage, do you expect limiting factors to dampen the growth over time, causing logistic growth? For example, in the case of carbon emissions, we could expect that, absent other factors, they would be tied closely to population values, which tend to change by percentage. If you look at carbon emissions over a short time span, the change would likely be exponential, but over long time spans we might see logistic growth because human population cannot continue to grow exponentially on earth forever.

statement.p: For each of the following situations, decide if the quantity described is best modelled with a linear, exponential, or logistic sequence.

ol.li: The volume of water in a bathtub as it is filled.
The number of people who have heard of a celebrity, measured over the course of the celebrity's career.
The air pressure of a bike tire that acquires a tiny leak.
The amount of toothpaste left in the tube, measured from when you bought it until it runs out.
The volume of a ball of dough, measured as it rises over the course of half an hour.
The volume of a ball of dough, if left to rise and forgotten all day.

We should expect that the rate at which water comes out of the tap is roughly constant, meaning that there is a constant amount of water added to the tub each second. Since the water in the tub is increasing by the same amount each time period, it is likely best modeled by an increasing linear sequence.

As with many types of information, how fast the name of a celebrity is currently spreading depends largely on how many people have already heard of them. The more people who already know about them, the more people their name gets passed on to. So we should expect the number of people who have heard of a celebrity to change by a percentage. However, this effect slows down as more and more people have heard of the celebrity, since it becomes more likely that everyone in a given social group has already heard about them. Towards the end of a celebrity's career, their name has likely already reached most people that will ever hear of it, and can't spread much further. Therefore, we should expect the growth to level out over time. So it probably makes the most sense to model this with a logistic sequence.

When the air pressure of the tire is higher, the air will leak out faster, but when it becomes lower, it will leak more slowly. Since the change in air pressure is tied to how high the pressure is, this is probably best modeled by a decreasing exponential function.

Given that you probably use about the same amount of toothpaste each time you brush your teeth, and that you do so consistently, the amount of toothpaste leaving the tube each day should be constant. So this is probably best modeled by a decreasing linear sequence.

Dough rises because of carbon dioxide released by yeast as it consumes sugar and starch to reproduce. So we should expect the volume of the dough to be correlated with the population of yeast cells within the dough. So since populations tend to change by percentage, we should expect the volume of the dough to change in the same way. Given only half an hour to rise, it's unlikely that the yeast population will be close to its carrying capacity within the dough, so this situation is probably best modeled by an increasing exponential sequence, rather than a logistic sequence.

If left to rise all day, however, it's likely that the rising will slow and eventually stop, as the yeast population's growth is limited by the amount of food available to it within the dough. Therefore, this situation is probably best modeled by a logistic sequence.
